Award.AwardTitle: Networked Knowledge and Preparedness for Zika

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

The principal investigator and his team will conduct approximately 300 interviews in order to collect data and then conduct an analysis of that data to further our understanding of how cultural and political contexts shape the ways people respond to epidemics. The interviews will be videotaped for public engagement and wider distribution. The resulting analysis will provide grounded guidance for policy makers and others seeking to understand the diversity of fears, risk perceptions, preparedness, and acceptable actions. The Zika epidemic will not likely end soon, though it is likely that there will be other infectious viruses of global importance.

Technical Summary

This primary goal of this project is the immediate collection of perishable data from groups in both rural and urban communities in three countries (Argentina, Mexico, and Brazil). The groups are selected for their importance to the epidemic processes (transmission and treatment of the disease and of information), and they include women of childbearing age, medical professionals, teachers, and youth, as well as the informal sector and the unemployed. The research team will collect qualitative baseline information on these groups by conducting approximately 100 interviews per country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Argentina

There are marked differences among the regions in social perceptions of the quality of the information received. In GBA (Buenos Aires Urban Area), we found a large majority perceive the information available is clear and vast, whereas in Andean and North-East Regions there is a negative perception. In these two regions, there was an information peak during the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro followed by a decline and total disappearance of the subject in the public sphere.This indicates the very brief shelf life during which positive change can be instigated.

As expected, higher socioeconomic sectors are more informed about the disease. However, the main factor is not related to their education level, but to the possibility of travel abroad. Those that anticipated the possibility of leaving sought information actively.In the GBA region, holiday planning and pregnancy planning acted as drivers for the search for information. The Internet was hardly consulted at all.Most heard report on the disease for the first time through TV and then went to hospitals for deeper information. In the four regions we investigated, there was a high level of confusion between Zika and Dengue, and many used their knowledge of Dengue, which is more familiar, to interpret the Zika phenomenon. Doctor’s knowledge about the disease is very different among the Regions: in the Andean area, far from Brazil, doctors alluded not to know the disease or to be informed at the level of a layperson. They state that neither in university instruction nor in the hospital institution the Zika was an issue of interest. The opposite case is that of the Northeast, close to Brazilian border, where the doctors were highly informed. 

With respect to the social perception of risk around Zika disease, most interviewees from all regions identified Zika with poverty, lack of hygiene and education, and low-income and / or rural areas. However, since there were no indigenous cases of infection in Argentina during the time of the interviews (all the patients were infected abroad), our data tend to strengthen the idea that people use the Dengue model (also associated with rurality and poverty) to think about the ‘Zika problem’.Faced with a possible infection with Zika, all respondents in all regions viewed their only option as asking for formal medical care, ruling out any alternative treatment or resort to traditional knowledge. The latter is possibly due to the novel, little-known character of the “foreign” disease.

Brazil

 

The main finding of this project in Brazil is that both members of the public and health professionals attended to health problems covered by the media. Consequently, interest in Zika virus was at its highest during the height of the microcephaly crisis in the country. This brings issues of visibility to the fore. While the virus manifested itself in the form of dramatic pictures of newborn babies with altered 
cranial circumference, which was broadcast in the media, the population was quite aware of the problem. Once the microcephaly crisis passed its peak, there was much less media coverage and decreased awareness of the problem. We explored both the more affected region of Northeastern Brazil and the less affected region of Southeastern Brazil, as well as different groups of respondents. A practical implication of this study is that the population should be made aware of the risk of infection at all times rather than during epidemiological peaks as well as about other forms of contagion besides insects.

 

With regard to fertility concerns in the context of Zika among women of reproductive age in Brazil, there is a perception that the consequences of having a child when one has Zika are greater for women than men, owing to the perception that men can leave but women cannot. In addition, women who are currently pregnant are conflicted over the use of mosquito repellent and have to weigh the benefits of repellent for preventing Zika with their concerns over whether repellent is bad for their unborn child.
